      12a
      Helical ribbons of Cadmium(II) and Zinc(II) dicarboxylates with bipyridyl-like chelates - syntheses, crystal structures and photoluminescence
      Zhang, Ling-Yun; Liu, Gao-Feng; Zheng, Shao-Liang; Ye, Bao-Hui; Zhang, Xian-Ming; Chen, Xiao-Ming
      European Journal of Inorganic Chemistry (2003), (16), 2965-2971CODEN: EJICFO; ISSN:1434-1948. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Four mixed-ligand complexes of [M(mpa)(phen)]n [M = Cd (1), Zn (2); mpa = m-phthalate, phen = 1,10-phenanthroline] and [M2(mpa)2(2,2'-bpy)2]n [M = Zn (3), Cd (4); 2,2'-bpy = 2,2'-bipyridine] were synthesized by the hydrothermal method, and their crystal structures were established by single-crystal x-ray diffraction. They all consist of 1-dimensional ribbons featuring dinuclear units. Both 1 and 2 crystallize isomorphously in the monoclinic space group P2/c and feature helical chains, while 3 and 4 crystallize in the triclinic space group P‾1. The 1-dimensional ribbons are assembled into three-dimensional networks by π-π stacking interactions. Compds. 1-4 show strong blue photoluminescence and are stable in air up to ∼402, 371, 365 and 370°, resp.

      12b
      d10 Metal complexes assembled from isomeric benzenedicarboxylates and 3-(2-pyridyl)pyrazole showing 1D chain structures: syntheses, structures and luminescent properties
      Hu, Tong-Liang; Zou, Ruo-Qiang; Li, Jian-Rong; Bu, Xian-He
      Dalton Transactions (2008), (10), 1302-1311CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Seven new d10 metal coordination polymers with isomeric benzenedicarboxylates and 3-(2-pyridyl)pyrazole ligands, [Zn2L2(1,2-BDC)(H2O)]n (1), {[Cd2(HL)2(1,2-BDC)2]·H2O}n (2), [Cd(HL)(1,2-BDC)(H2O)]n (3), [Zn(HL)(1,3-BDC)(H2O)·3H2O]n (4), [Cd2L2(1,3-BDC)(H2O)]n (5), [Zn(HL)2(1,4-BDC)]n (6) and [Cd(HL)2(1,4-BDC)]n (7) (BDC = benzenedicarboxylate, HL = 3-(2-pyridyl)pyrazole), were synthesized and structurally characterized by elemental anal., IR and x-ray diffraction. Single-crystal x-ray analyses reveal that each complex displays a different 1-dimensional (1D) chain structure. In all complexes, the BDCs act as bridging ligands, exhibiting rich coordination modes to link metal ions. The three BDC isomers exhibit different coordination modes: μ1-η1:η1/μ3-η2:η1, μ3-η1:η2/μ3-η2:η1, μ2-η1:η1/μ1-η1:η0 and μ1-η1:η1/μ1-η1:η0 for 1,2-BDC, μ1-η1:η1/μ1-η1:η0 and μ1-η1:η0/μ2-η2:η1 for 1,3-BDC, and μ1-η1:η0/μ1-η0:η1, μ1-η1:η0/μ1-η1:η0 and μ1-η1:η1/μ1-η1:η1 for 1,4-BDC, resp. In 1-7, HL acts as a simple bidentate chelate ligand (2-4, 6-7), similar to 2,2'-bipyridine, or as a tridentate chelate-bridging ligand (1, 5) via deprotonation of the pyrazolyl NH group and coordination of the pyrazolyl N atom to a 2nd metal ion. The structural differences indicate that the backbone of such dicarboxylate ligands plays an important role in governing the structures of such metal-org. coordination architectures, and the chelating bipyridyl-like ligand HL gives these coordination polymers with 1-dimensional structures by occupying the coordination sites of metal ions. The solid-state room temp. photoluminescent properties of 1-7 were also studied.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXisVKjtLw%253D&md5=e9a49f6017fd876716e7d1be99037152

      Synthesis and Single Crystal Investigation of Two-Dimensional Rectangular Network [M(4,4'-bpy)(Phth)(H2O)]n·2H2O with Small Neutral Cavities
      Suresh, Eringathodi; Boopalan, Kamla; Jasra, Raksh Vir; Bhadbhade, Mohan Madhav
      Inorganic Chemistry (2001), 40 (16), 4078-4080CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      In order to construct a neutral cavity-contg. porous networks with two different edge lengths, two isostructural metal-org. neutral rectangular grids of [M[4,4'-bpy](phth)(H2O)2]n (M = Co 2+ 1a, M = Cd 2+ 1b, 4, 4'-bpy = 4,4'-bipyridyl, phth = 1,2-benzenedicarboxylate) were synthesized. The formation of 1a and 1b are confirmed by single crystal x-ray diffraction, IR, and anal. data.

      Two-step adsorption/desorption on a jungle-gym-type porous coordination polymer
      Uemura, Kazuhiro; Yamasaki, Yukari; Komagawa, Yuki; Tanaka, Kazuhiro; Kita, Hidetoshi
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2007), 46 (35), 6662-6665CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Unique two-step isotherms were obsd. for the adsorption/desorption of propan-2-ol on [{Zn2(1,4-benzenedicarboxylate)2(1,4- diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane)}n] with hydro-phobic open spaces. The isotherms were characterized by means of thermal anal. and single-crystal X-ray diffraction.

      13b
      Self-Assembly of Metal-Organic Coordination Polymers Constructed from a Versatile Multipyridyl Ligand: Diversity of Coordination Modes and Structures
      Liang, Xiao-Qiang; Zhou, Xin-Hui; Chen, Chao; Xiao, Hong-Ping; Li, Yi-Zhi; Zuo, Jing-Lin; You, Xiao-Zeng
      Crystal Growth & Design (2009), 9 (2), 1041-1053CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
      Six d10 metal metal-org. coordination polymers, {[Zn2(Htpim)2(tp)2]·2H2O}n (1), {[Cd3(H0.5tpim)4(pa)2(H2O)2]·5H2O}n (2), [Zn(Htpim)(Htma)]n (3), {[Zn4(Htpim)4(ipt)4]·2H2O}n (4), [Cd(Htpim)(ca)]n (5), and {[Cd4(Htpim)2(D-ca)4(H2O)2]·5H2O}n (6) (Htpim = 2,4,5-tri(4-pyridyl)imidazole, H2tp = terephthalic acid, H2pa = phthalic acid, H3tma = trimesic acid, H2ipt = isophthalic acid, H2ca = racemic camphor acid, D-H2ca = D-camphor acid), were prepd. and structurally characterized. In all complexes, the rigid ligand Htpim exhibits different coordination modes and gives various architectures. Complex 1 shows a two-dimensional (2D) network with (6,3) topol., where hydrogen-bonding interactions further link these sheets to a three-dimensional (3D) supramol. structure. Complex 2 exhibits a 2-dimensional layer with (53)(54) network topol. Complex 3 is a corrugated 2-dimensional layer with (4,4) topol., and the sepd. layers are connected through weak π-π stacking interactions to generate a 3-dimensional supramol. architecture. Complex 4 is a rhombic 2-dimensional layer with (4,4) topol., and the 3-dimensional overlapped array is formed by hydrogen-bonding and π-π stacking interactions. A 3-dimensional diamondoid framework with 4-fold interpenetration is found in 5. Complex 6 contains a complicated 3-dimensional framework, and the vacancy is occupied by the guest water mols. Their luminescent properties were studied in the solid state.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXpsF2m&md5=b898ea75f9180806c6a49d07923e86f6
      (c) Chen, B. L.; Zhao, X.; Putkham, A.; Hong, K.; Lobkovsky, E. B.; Hurtado, E. J.; Fletcher, A. J.; Thomas, K. M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2008, 130, 6411
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      13c
      Surface Interactions and Quantum Kinetic Molecular Sieving for H2 and D2 Adsorption on a Mixed Metal-Organic Framework Material
      Chen, Banglin; Zhao, Xuebo; Putkham, Apipong; Hong, Kunlun; Lobkovsky, Emil B.; Hurtado, Eric J.; Fletcher, Ashleigh J.; Thomas, K. Mark
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2008), 130 (20), 6411-6423CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      A rational strategy was used to immobilize open metal sites in ultramicroporosity for stronger binding of multiple H2 mols. per unsatd. metal site for H2 storage applications. The synthesis and structure of a mixed Zn/Cu metal-org. framework material Zn3(BDC)3[Cu(Pyen)]·(DMF)5(H2O)5 (H2BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid and PyenH2 = (5-methyl-4-hydroxopyridine-3-methylene)ethylenediaminecarbaldehyde) is reported. Desolvation provides a bimodal porous structure Zn3(BDC)3[Cu(Pyen)] (M'MOF 1) with narrow porosity (<0.56 nm) and an array of pores in the bc crystallog. plane where the adsorbate-adsorbent interactions are maximized by both the presence of open Cu centers and overlap of the potential energy fields from pore walls. The H2 and D2 adsorption isotherms for M'MOF 1 at 77.3 and 87.3 K were reversible with virtually no hysteresis. Methods for detn. of the isosteric enthalpies of H2 and D2 adsorption were compared. A virial model gave the best agreement (av. deviation <1 std. deviation) with the isotherm data. This was used in conjunction with the van't Hoff isochore giving isosteric enthalpies at zero surface coverage of 12.29 ± 0.53 and 12.44 ± 0.50 kJ mol-1 for H2 and D2 adsorption, resp. This is the highest value so far obsd. for H adsorption on a porous material. The enthalpy of adsorption, decreases with increasing amt. adsorbed to 9.5 kJ mol-1 at .ltorsim.≈1.9 mmol g-1 (2 H2 or D2 mols. per Cu corresponding to adsorption on both sides of planar Cu open centers) and is virtually unchanged in the range 1.9-3.6 mmol g-1. Virial anal. of isotherms at 87.3 K is also consistent with 2 H2 or D2 mols. being bound to each open Cu center. The adsorption kinetics follow a double exponential model, corresponding to diffusion along 2 types of pores, a slow component with high activation energy (13.35 ± 0.59 kJ mol-1) for the narrow pores and a faster component with low activation energy (8.56 ± 0.41 kJ mol-1). The D2 adsorption kinetic consts. for both components were significantly faster than the corresponding H2 kinetics for specific pressure increments and had slightly lower activation energies than the corresponding values for H2 adsorption. The kD2/kH2 ratio for the slow component was 1.62 ± 0.07, while the fast component was 1.38 ± 0.04 at 77.3 K, and the corresponding ratios were smaller at 87.3 K. These observations of kinetic isotope quantum mol. sieving in porous materials are due to the larger zero-point energy for the lighter H2, resulting in slower adsorption kinetics compared with the heavier D2. A combination of open metal centers and confinement in ultramicroporosity leads to a high enthalpy for H2 adsorption over a wide range of surface coverage and quantum effects influence diffusion of H2 and D2 in pores in M'MOF 1.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXltVyjsLo%253D&md5=cd9993fbfa093dfecfd6324ec8f7d042
      (d) Reineke, T. M.; Eddaoudi, M.; O’Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 1999, 38, 2590
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      13d
      A microporous lanthanide - organic framework
      Reineke, Theresa M.; Eddaoudi, Mohamed; O'Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, Omar M.
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (1999), 38 (17), 2590-2594CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH)
      The synthesis and crystal structure of Tb(bdc)NO3·2DMF (bdc = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate) is reported, and its desolvated form is shown to have a stable zeolite-like framework. Each terbium is bonded to eight oxygen atoms, 4 from 4 different bdc ligands, 2 from a bidentate nitrate and 2 from 2 DMF ligands. Tb(bdc)NO3 is capable of reversible mol. sorption and maintains its microporosity in the absence of included guests.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXmt1arsbo%253D&md5=afcee9bc50ccc95b9390a94c731f5cd2

      (a) Yang, J.; Li, G. D.; Cao, J. J.; Yue, Q.; Li, G. H.; Chen, J. S. Chem.—Eur. J. 2007, 13, 3248
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      14a
      Structural variation from 1D to 3D: effects of ligands and solvents on the construction of lead(II)-organic coordination polymers
      Yang, Jin; Li, Guo-Dong; Cao, Jun-Jun; Yue, Qi; Li, Guang-Hua; Chen, Jie-Sheng
      Chemistry - A European Journal (2007), 13 (11), 3248-3261CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      PbII coordination polymers [Pb(ndc)(dpp)] (1), [Pb(ndc)(ptcp)]·0.5H2O (2), [Pb(ndc)(dppz)] (3), [Pb(ndc)(tcpn)2] (4), [Pb2(ndc)2(tcpp)] (5), [Pb(Hndc)2]·H2O (6), [Pb(ndc)(dma)] (7), [Pb(bdc)(dma)] (8), [Pb(trans-chdc)(H2O)] (9), and [Pb2(cis-chdc)2]·NHMe2 (10), where ndc = 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylate, dpp = 4,7-diphenyl-1,10-phenanthroline, ptcp = 2-phenyl-1H-1,3,7,8-tetraazacyclopenta[l]phenanthrene, dppz = dipyrido[3,2-a:2',3'-c]phenazine, tcpn = 2-(1H-1,3,7,8-tetraazacyclopenta[l]phenanthren-2-yl)naphthol, tcpp = 4-(1H-1,3,7,8-tetraazacyclopenta[l]phenanthren-2-yl)phenol, dma = N,N-dimethylacetamide, bdc = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, and chdc = 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylate, were synthesized from a hydrothermal or solvothermal reaction system by varying the ligands or the solvents. Compds. 1-5 crystallize with an N-donor chelating ligand and an arom. dicarboxylate linker. Compds. 1-4 are 1-dimensional polymers with different π-π stacking interactions, whereas compd. 5 consists of 2-dimensional layers. The structures of compds. 7, 8, and 10 are 3-dimensional frameworks formed by connection of the Pb centers by org. acid ligands. Compd. 7 is chiral although the ndc ligand is achiral, while the framework of 8 is a typical 3-dimensional (3,4)-connected net. Compd. 10 is the 1st example of PbII wheel cluster [Pb8O8] units bridged by carboxylate groups. Compd. 6 contains ID chains which are further extended to a 3-dimensional structure by π-π interactions. Compd. 9 consists of a 2-dimensional network constructed by PbII centers and trans-chdc ligands. The structural differences between 7 and 8 and between 9 and 10 indicate the importance of solvents for framework formation of the coordination polymers. By varying the solvent the cis and trans conformations of H2chdc in 9 and 10 were sepd. completely. The photoluminescence and nonlinear optical properties of the coordination polymers also were studied.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      2D and 3D structures of La-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylates (chdc) coordination networks were constructed using flexible chdc ligands which can have cis and trans conformations. Structure is controlled by the soln. pH in the hydrothermal reaction conditions. 2 Crystal structures are reported for polymeric complexes contg. both isomers.

      Synthesis, Structure, and Fluorescence of the Novel Cadmium(II)-Trimesate Coordination Polymers with Different Coordination Architectures
      Dai, Jing-Cao; Wu, Xin-Tao; Fu, Zhi-Yong; Cui, Chuan-Peng; Hu, Sheng-Min; Du, Wen-Xin; Wu, Li-Ming; Zhang, Han-Hui; Sun, Rui-Qing
      Inorganic Chemistry (2002), 41 (6), 1391-1396CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      Three novel complexes, Cd3tma2·13H2O (1), Cd3tma2·dabco·2H2O (2), and Cd3Htma3·8H2O (3) (tma = trimesate, dabco = 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane), of Cd(II)-trimesate coordination polymers were obtained from hydrothermal reaction. 1 (C18H32O25Cd3) crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c [a = 18.985(2) Å, b 7.3872(6), c 20.432(2) Å, β 97.1660(10)°, and Z = 4]. 2 (C24H22N2O14Cd3) crystallizes in the monoclinic P2(1)/c space group [a = 10.1323(2) Å, b 19.5669(5), c 13.15880(10) Å, β 108.9810(10)°, and Z = 4]. 3 (C27H28O26Cd3) belongs to the trigonal P31c space group [a = 15.7547(3) Å, b 15.7547(3), c 7.93160(10) Å, and Z = 2]. 1 (C18H32O25Cd3) crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c [a = 18.985(2), b 7.3872(6), c 20.432(2) Å, β 97.1660(10)°, and Z = 4]; 2 (C24H22N2O14Cd3) crystallizes in the monoclinic P2(1)/c space group [a = 10.1323(2), b 19.5669(5), c 13.15880(10) Å, β 108.9810(10)°, and Z = 4]; 3 (C27H28O26Cd3) belongs to the trigonal P31c space group [a = 15.7547(3), b 15.7547(3), c 7.93160(10) Å, and Z = 2]. The Cd(II) centers in the three complexes are bridged by tma ligands in the coordination fashion of unidentate, bridging unidentate, bidentate, chelating bis-bidentate, chelating/bridging bis-bidentate, or chelating/bridging bidentate to form the T-shaped mol. bilayer motif for 1, chicken-wire-like motif for 2, and honeycomb-like porous structure for 3, resp., in which the T-shaped mol. bilayer motif and chicken-wire-like motif are further interlinked in interdigitating or alternating fashion to construct the different coordination architectures. These three complexes exhibit strong fluorescent emission bands at 355 nm (λex = 220 nm) for 1, 437 nm (λex = 365 nm) for 2, and 353 nm (λex = 218 nm) for 3 in the solid state at room temp.

      Leininger, Stefan; Olenyuk, Bogdan; Stang, Peter J.

      19b
      Molecular Tectonics: From Simple Tectons to Complex Molecular Networks
      Hosseini, Mir Wais
      Accounts of Chemical Research (2005), 38 (4), 313-323CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. Mol. networks in the cryst. phase are infinite periodic mol. assemblies formed under self-assembly conditions between self-complementary or complementary tectons. These millimeter-size structures may be regarded as hypermols. formed by supramol. synthesis using reversible intertecton interactions. Mol. tectonics, based on mol. recognition events and their iteration, is the approach dealing with design and prepn. of mol. networks in the solid state. In this Account, an overview of the rational behind this approach is presented. A variety of mol. networks based on van der Waals interactions and hydrogen and coordination bonding possessing diverse connectivity and topol. are discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXjs1KktQ%253D%253D&md5=6080c4b44c88ef8b07dd7baf4c82cd4d

      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar

      From molecules to crystal engineering. Supramolecular isomerism and polymorphism in network solids
      Moulton, Brian; Zaworotko, Michael J.
      Chemical Reviews (Washington, D. C.) (2001), 101 (6), 1629-1658CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
      A review with 299 refs. on how the advances in supramol. chem. have impacted the manner in which chemists view the existence of single crystals and the design of new cryst. phases. Coordination polymers, H-bonded networks, and supramol. isomerism and polymorphism are considered.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXjtlyqtrg%253D&md5=00fbfe863055d07d1773be77dc52f023
      (d) Holliday, B. J.; Mirkin, C. A. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2001, 40, 2022
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      19d
      Strategies for the construction of supramolecular compounds through coordination chemistry
      Holliday, Bradley J.; Mirkin, Chad A.
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2001), 40 (11), 2022-2043CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH)
      A review with 390 refs. is presented on strategies for the synthesis of supramol. coordination complexes. Synthetic org. chemists enjoy the luxury of having a large collection of reliable reactions at their disposal for prepg. small mols., mesoscopic structures, and polymers. Coordination chemists, however, are faced with the fact that transition metal chem., when normalized for the no. of transition metals, has relatively few high-yielding reactions, when compared to the chem. of carbon, for prepg. even small mol. structures. This lack of control is manifested, in large part, in the weak metal-ligand interactions found in coordination complexes as compared with the strong covalent bonds in org. compds. Weak bonding often translates into many reaction pathways that are not substantially different from an energetic point of view, and therefore, results in poor selectivity. As a result, many coordination chemists in recent years have come to the realization that it may be easier and more productive to develop straightforward and reliable routes to mesoscopic supramol. structures by capitalizing on the modest collection of high-yielding reactions in coordination chem., the directional bonding afforded by metal centers, and strategies aimed at taking advantage of the weak metal bonds found in coordination complexes. Three emerging synthetic strategies, the symmetry-interaction, directional-bonding, and weak-link synthetic approaches, all use metal centers as structural building blocks to rationally assemble mol. components into supramol. metallocyclophanes. These three approaches are discussed herein, and the fundamental principles underlying each as well as their capabilities are compared and contrasted.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXksVOis7w%253D&md5=631f91cc7c3c10e11cbffc22174dc553
      (e) Liu, J. Q.; Wang, Y. Y.; Ma, L. F.; Zhong, F.; Zeng, X. R.; Wu, W. P.; Shi, Q. Z. Inorg. Chem. Commun. 2007, 979
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar

It exhibits a novel (2-D → 3D) 3-fold parallel interpenetrating architecture that was obtained for the 1st time from the self-assembly of grid-contg. 2-dimensional (4, 4) layer motifs. The fluorescent property of 1 is discussed.

      Interlocked Chiral Nanotubes Assembled from Quintuple Helices
      Cui, Yong; Lee, Suk Joong; Lin, Wenbin
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2003), 125 (20), 6014-6015CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Homochiral helical chains NiL1,2(acac)2 (I, R = H = L1; R = OCH2CH2OCH2CH2OCH2CH2O = L2) were rationally synthesized from C2-sym. 1,1-binaphthyl-6,6'-bipyridine ligands and linear metal-connecting points, Ni(acac)2. Five such homochiral helixes assoc. in parallel to form nanotubes of 2 × 2 nm in dimensions which further intertwine to form periodically ordered, interlocked nanotubular architectures that possess nanometer-scale open channels and have high affinity for arom. mols. Chiral crown ethers also were successfully incorporated into the walls of these nanotubes, which promises to lead to novel chiral zeolitic materials applicable in enantioselective processes.

      Unique (3,12)-Connected Porous Lanthanide-Organic Frameworks Based on Ln4O4 Clusters: Synthesis, Crystal Structures, Luminescence, and Magnetism
      Li, Xia; Sun, Hao-Ling; Wu, Xiao-Shuo; Qiu, Xiao; Du, Miao
      Inorganic Chemistry (Washington, DC, United States) (2010), 49 (4), 1865-1871CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      Three porous lanthanide-org. frameworks, [Ln4(OH)4(3-SBA)4(H2O)4]·nH2O [Ln = EuIII (1), n = 10; GdIII (2), n = 10; TbIII (3), n = 8; 3-SBA = 3-sulfobenzoate], were prepd. by a hydrothermal synthesis method. They are isomorphous and crystallize in a tetragonal system with space group P421c. The structure can be considered to be built up by cubane-like [Ln4(OH)4]8+ secondary building units, which are further connected by 3-SBA to form a 3-dimensional coordination framework with 1-dimensional pores along the c direction for accommodation of novel T8(3) water tapes or zigzag water chains. Also, in these compds., the [Ln4(OH)4]8+ units and 3-SBA ligands serve as 12-connected and 3-connected nodes, resp., resulting in a unique (3,12)-connected framework with the Schlafli symbol of (43)4(420.628.818). The luminescent properties of the EuIII (1) and TbIII (3) complexes were studied, showing characteristic emissions at room temp. Variable-temp. magnetic susceptibility studies indicate that the GdIII complex 2 displays weak antiferromagnetic coupling through μ3-OH- pathways.

      Syntheses, Structures, and Photoluminescence of Five New Metal-Organic Frameworks Based on Flexible Tetrapyridines and Aromatic Polycarboxylate Acids
      Hu, Jin-Song; Shang, Yong-Jia; Yao, Xiao-qiang; Qin, Ling; Li, Yi-Zhi; Guo, Zi-Jian; Zheng, He-Gen; Xue, Zi-Ling
      Crystal Growth & Design (2010), 10 (6), 2676-2684CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
      Solvothermal reactions of tetrakis(4-pyridyloxymethylene)methane (TPOM) with deprotonated 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (H2bdc) or 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid (5-OH-H2bdc) in the presence of nitrates of cadmium, zinc, and cobalt in H2O or H2O/DMF produced five new complexes, namely, {[Cd2(TPOM)(bdc)2]·(H2O)5(DMF)}n (1), {[Zn2(TPOM)(bdc)2]·(H2O)4}n (2), {[Zn2(TPOM)(bdc)2]·(H2O)}n (3), {[Co2(TPOM)(5-OH-bdc)2(H2O)2]·(H2O)5}n (4), and {[Cd2(TPOM)(5-OH-bdc)2]·(H2O)2}n (5). These complexes were characterized by elemental anal., IR spectroscopy, and x-ray single-crystal diffraction. Complex 1 reveals a 2-fold interpenetrating three-dimensional (3D) framework with pcu topol. constructed from binuclear Cd clusters and TPOM ligands. In addn., the expt. of single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SC-SC) structural transformations upon guest exchange was tested. Zn complexes 2 and 3 possess different 3D frameworks and are prepd. from TPOM and H2bdc under different reaction conditions. In complexes 4 and 5, TPOM and 5-OH-H2bdc link Co or Cd centers to generate 3D interpenetrating frameworks with bbf and qtz topol. In addn., thermal stabilities and photochem. properties of these new complexes in the solid state have been studied.

      (a) Manna, S. C.; Zangrando, E.; Ribas, J.; Chaudhuri, N. R. Eur. J. Inorg. Chem. 2008, 1400

      21a
      Supramolecular isomerism in coordination polymers of isophthalato-bridged MnII complexes using 4,4'-dipyridyl N,N'-dioxide
      Manna, Subal Chandra; Zangrando, Ennio; Ribas, Joan; Chaudhuri, Nirmalendu Ray
      European Journal of Inorganic Chemistry (2008), (9), 1400-1405CODEN: EJICFO; ISSN:1434-1948. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Manganese polymeric dicarboxylate forms a supramol. assembly in solid state in one-pot three-component reaction of Mn(2+) salt with isophthalate dianion (isop) and 4,4'-bipyridine-N,N'-dioxide (dpyo). The supramol. structure is formed by (H2O)2Mn2(μ-isop)2 moieties in which carboxylate groups act as chelate and bridging ligands, the 4,4'-bipyridine-N,N'-dioxide mols. being in uncoordinated or bridging mode. A one-pot reaction of MnII, 1,3-(O2C)2C6H42- and 4,4'-dipyridyl N,N'-dioxide in water/methanol (1:1) causes self-assembly resulting in two 3D supramol. isomers of the same stoichiometry, colorless {[Mn(isop)(H2O)2]·(dpyo)·(H2O)}n (1) and pink {[Mn(isop)(H2O)(dpyo)0.5]·(dpyo)0.5·(H2O)2}n (2). Both isomers crystallize in the same crystal system (triclinic) and space group (P‾1). The structural detn. of 1 reveals an isophthalato-bridged 1D coordination polymer, {[Mn(isop)(H2O)2]}n, having 16- and 8-membered rings where isophthalate acts simultaneously as chelating and bridging ligand connected to three metal centers. In isomer 2 the 1D chains transform to a 2D arrangement through bridging dpyo that replaces a water mol. at metal axial position. Both the crystal structures result in a 3D supramol. network achieved through H-bonding among the 1D (in 1) or 2D (in 2) coordination polymers with lattice water and dpyo mols. and also by means of π-π interactions in 1. Low-temp. magnetic measurement indicates antiferromagnetic interaction in both the isomers and the best fits are given by the exchange parameters J = -0.56 ± 0.02 cm-1, g = 2.01 ± 0.01 and R = 3.1 × 10-5 for 1 and J = -1.06 ± 0.03 cm-1, g = 2.01 ± 0.01 and R = 2.8 × 10-5 for 2.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXltFShtbw%253D&md5=649c9a8df1ad89e339aa0deaa5341eb9
      (b) Mir, M. H.; Kitagawa, S.; Vittal, J. J. Inorg. Chem. 2008, 47, 7728
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      21b
      Two- and Three-fold Interpenetrated Metal-Organic Frameworks from One-Pot Crystallization
      Mir, Mohammad Hedayetullah; Kitagawa, Susumu; Vittal, Jagadese J.
      Inorganic Chemistry (Washington, DC, United States) (2008), 47 (17), 7728-7733CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      Two different three-dimensional interpenetrating metal-org. frameworks, {[Co(bpe)(muco)](DMF)(H2O)}n (1) and {[Co(bpe)(muco)(H2O)2]·4(H2O)}n (2) [bpe = 4,4'-bipyridylethylene, H2muco = trans,trans-muconic acid] were co-crystd. in a 1-pot reaction. This work offers some insights into the intricacy of designing coordination polymers with variable interpenetration, showing new modes of entanglements. Single crystal x-ray diffraction analyses reveal that the compd. 1 has a highly distorted cubic (α-Po) net with 2-fold interpenetrated structures while compd. 2 displays a 3-fold interpenetrating network with an unprecedented 66 topol. which is different from other known 4-connected nets such as diamond or hexagonal diamond. Despite varied interpenetrations, both compds. retain open channels, filled with aggregated guest solvent mols. As far as the ratios of Co/muco/bpe are concerned, these two complexes can be considered as supramol. isomers. Formation of a particular isomer in major quantity can be obtained by varying the countercation of the muconate salt in different solvents, by layering, and by changing the order of the components.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXptVGjtr8%253D&md5=e6335ed0e0ab75c76eeb4b25bca91674
    22. 22
      (a) Seneviratne, D. S.; Uddin, M. J.; Swayambunathan, V.; Schlegel, H. B.; Endicott, J. F. Inorg. Chem. 2002, 41, 1502
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      22a
      Characteristics and Properties of Metal-to-Ligand Charge-Transfer Excited States in 2,3-Bis(2-pyridyl)pyrazine and 2,2'-Bipyridine Ruthenium Complexes. Perturbation-Theory-Based Correlations of Optical Absorption and Emission Parameters with Electrochemistry and Thermal Kinetics and Related Ab Initio Calculations
      Seneviratne, Dhehinie S.; Uddin, Md. Jamal; Swayambunathan, V.; Schlegel, H. Bernhard; Endicott, John F.
      Inorganic Chemistry (2002), 41 (6), 1502-1517CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      The absorption, emission, and IR spectra, metal (Ru) and ligand (PP) half-wave potentials, and ab initio calcns. on the ligands (PP) are compared for several [LnRu(PP)]2+ and [{LnRu}dpp{RuL'n}]4+ complexes, where Ln and L'n = (bpy)2 or (NH3)4 and PP = 2,2'-bipyridine (bpy), 2,3-bis(2-pyridyl)pyrazine (dpp), 2,3-bis(2-pyridyl)quinoxaline (dpq), or 2,3-bis(2-pyridyl)benzoquinoxaline (dpb). The energy of the metal-to-ligand charge-transfer (MLCT) absorption max. (hνmax) varies in nearly direct proportion to the difference between RuIII/RuII and (PP)/(PP)- half-wave potentials, ΔE1/2, for the monometallic complexes but not for the bimetallic complexes. The MLCT spectra of [(NH3)4Ru(dpp)]2+ exhibit three prominent visible-near-UV absorptions, compared to two for [(NH3)4Ru(bpy)]2+, and are not easily reconciled with the MLCT spectra of [{(NH3)4Ru}dpp{RuLn}]4+. The ab initio calcns. indicate that the two lowest energy π* orbitals are not much different in energy in the PP ligands (they correlate with the degenerate π* orbitals of benzene) and that both contribute to the obsd. MLCT transitions. The LUMO energies calcd. for the monometallic complexes correlate strongly with the obsd. hνmax (cor. for variations in metal contribution). The LUMO computed for dpp correlates with LUMO + 1 of pyrazine. This inversion of the order of the two lowest energy π* orbitals is unique to dpp in this series of ligands. Configurational mixing of the ground and MLCT excited states is treated as a small perturbation of the overall energies of the metal complexes, resulting in a contribution εs to the ground-state energy. The fraction of charge delocalized, αDA2, is expected to attenuate the reorganizational energy, χreorg, by a factor of approx. (1-4αDA2 + αDA4), relative to the limit where there is no charge delocalization. This appears to be a substantial effect for these complexes (αDA2equiv. 0.1 for RuII/bpy), and it leads to smaller reorganizational energies for emission than for absorption. Reorganizational energies are inferred from the bandwidths found in Gaussian analyses of the emission and/or absorption spectra. Exchange energies are estd. from the Stokes shifts combined with perturbation-theory-based relation between the reorganizational energies for absorption and emission values. The results indicate that εs is dominated by terms that contribute to electron delocalization between metal and PP ligand. This inference is supported by the large shifts in the N-H stretching frequency of coordinated NH3 as the no. of PP ligands is increased. The measured properties of the bpy and dpp ligands seem to be very similar, but electron delocalization appears to be slightly larger (10-40%) and the exchange energy contributions appear to be comparable (e.g., ∼1.7 × 103 cm-1 in [Ru(bpy)2dpp]2+ compared to ∼1.3 × 103 cm-1 in the bpy analog).
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XhsV2hsbw%253D&md5=c6e2de2b41b6601e799f2f6fa45cc2d2
      (b) Castellano, F. N.; Henryk, M.; Gryczynski, I.; Lakowicz, J. R. Inorg. Chem. 1997, 36, 5548
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      22b
      Creation of Metal-to-Ligand Charge Transfer Excited States with Two-Photon Excitation
      Castellano, Felix N.; Malak, Henryk; Gryczynski, Ignacy; Lakowicz, Joseph R.
      Inorganic Chemistry (1997), 36 (24), 5548-5551CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      We examd. the steady state and time-resolved emission spectral properties of [Ru(bpy)3]2+ and [Ru(bpy)2(dcb)]2+, where bpy is 2,2'-bipyridine and dcb is 2,2'-bipyridine-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid, in fluid soln. when excited with 90 fs pulses from a mode-locked Ti/sapphire laser. Over the wavelength range 820-900 nm, both complexes displayed two-photon excitation as obsd. by a quadratic dependence of the emission intensity on incident power. Steady state emission and time-resolved frequency-domain intensity decay measurements revealed that two-photon excitation of each complex resulted in the same emission spectra and single-exponential decays as obsd. for one-photon excitation at a variety of temps. in different solvents. The two-photon excitation cross section of [Ru(bpy)3]2+ measured at 880 nm was detd. to be 4.3 × 10-50 cm4 s/photon. These results clearly show that metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) excited states can in fact be obtained through multiphoton processes.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2sXmvFCgtLc%253D&md5=299e4227e003fdf466e1caf0c62a25bc
    23. 23
      Bauer, C. A.; Timofeeva, T. V.; Settersten, T. B.; Patterson, B. D.; Liu, V. H.; Simmons, B. A.; Allendorf, M. D. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2007, 129, 7136
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      23
      Influence of Connectivity and Porosity on Ligand-Based Luminescence in Zinc Metal-Organic Frameworks
      Bauer, Christina A.; Timofeeva, Tatiana V.; Settersten, Thomas B.; Patterson, Brian D.; Liu, Vincent H.; Simmons, Blake A.; Allendorf, Mark D.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2007), 129 (22), 7136-7144CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Applications of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) require close correlation between their structure and function. The authors describe the prepn. and characterization of two Zn MOFs based on a flexible and emissive linker mol., stilbene, which retains its luminescence within these solid materials. Reaction of trans-4,4'-stilbenedicarboxylic acid (H2L) and zinc nitrate in DMF yielded a dense 2-dimensional network, Zn3L3(DMF)2 (1), featuring Zn in both octahedral and tetrahedral coordination environments connected by trans-stilbene links. Similar reaction in N,N-diethylformamide (DEF) at higher temps., followed by replacement of solvent in workup, resulted in a porous, 3-dimensional framework structure, Zn4OL3·(DMF)(CHCl3) (2). This framework consists of two interpenetrating cubic lattices, each featuring basic Zn carboxylate vertexes joined by trans-stilbene, analogous to the isoreticular MOF (IRMOF) series. The optical properties of both 1 and 2 correlate with the local ligand environments obsd. in the crystal structures. Steady-state and time-resolved spectroscopic measurements reveal that the stilbene linkers in the dense structure 1 exhibit a small degree of interchromophore coupling. In contrast, the stilbenoid units in 2 display very little interaction in this low-d. 3-dimensional framework, with excitation and emission spectra characteristic of monomeric stilbenes, similar to the dicarboxylic acid in dil. soln. In both cases, the rigidity of the stilbene linker increases upon coordination to the inorg. units through inhibition of torsion about the central ethylene bond, resulting in luminescent crystals with increased emission lifetimes compared to solns. of trans-stilbene. The emission spectrum of 2 depends on the nature of the incorporated solvent mols., suggesting use of this or related materials in sensor applications.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXltlWlurs%253D&md5=d4fb4e7121ad3251fba2c481c1ca2c49

        A review. The authors discuss the title topic and applications such as LEDs and luminescent sensors.

        1b
        Hydrogen storage in metal-organic frameworks
        Murray, Leslie J.; Dinca, Mircea; Long, Jeffrey R.
        Chemical Society Reviews (2009), 38 (5), 1294-1314CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review of current status of hydrogen storage within metal-org. frameworks. Microporous metal-org. frameworks, having exceptionally high surface areas and chem.-tunable structures, have recently emerged as some of the most promising candidate materials. Particular emphasis is given to the relationships between structural features and the enthalpy of hydrogen adsorption, spectroscopic methods for probing framework-H2 interactions, and strategies for improving storage capacity.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXkvVamuro%253D&md5=f652ac03772753d7f80244564a80e6f0
        (c) Jia, Q. X.; Tian, H.; Zhang, J. Y.; Gao, E. Q. Chem.—Eur. J. 2011, 17, 1040
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1c
        Diverse Structures and Magnetism of Cobalt(II) and Manganese(II) Compounds with Mixed Azido and Carboxylato Bridges Induced by Methylpyridinium Carboxylates
        Jia, Qin-Xiang; Tian, Hua; Zhang, Jian-Yong; Gao, En-Qing
        Chemistry--A European Journal (2011), 17 (3), 1040-1051, S1040/1-S1040/5CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Herein the authors present a systematic study of the structures and magnetic properties of six coordination compds. with mixed azide and zwitterionic carboxylate ligands, [M(N3)2(2-mpc)] (2-mpc = N-methylpyridinium-2-carboxylate; M = Co for 1 and Mn for 2), [M(N3)2(4-mpc)] (4-mpc = N-methylpyridinium-4-carboxylate; M = Co for 3 and Mn for 4), [Co3(N3)6(3-mpc)2(MeOH)2] (5), and [Mn3(N3)6(3-mpc)2] (6; 3-mpc = N-methylpyridinium-3-carboxylate). Compds. 1-3 consist of 1-dimensional uniform chains with (μ-EO-N3)2(μ-COO) triple bridges (EO = end-on); 5 is also a chain compd. but with alternating [(μ-EO-N3)2(μ-COO)] triple and [(EO-N3)2] double bridges; Compd. 4 contains two-dimensional layers with alternating [(μ-EO-N3)2(μ-COO)] triple, [(μ-EO-N3)(μ-COO)] double, and (EE-N3) single bridges (EE=end-to-end); 6 is a layer compd. in which chains similar to those in 5 are cross-linked by a μ3-1,1,3-N3 azido group. Magnetically, the three CoII compds. (1, 3, and 5) all exhibit intrachain ferromagnetic interactions but show distinct bulk properties: 1 displays relaxation dynamics at very low temp., 3 is an antiferromagnet with field-induced metamagnetism due to weak antiferromagnetic interchain interactions, and 5 behaves as a noninnocent single-chain magnet influenced by weak antiferromagnetic interchain interactions. The magnetic differences can be related to the interchain interactions through π-π stacking influenced by different substitution positions in the ligands and/or different magnitudes of intrachain coupling. All of the MnII compds. show overall intrachain/intralayer antiferromagnetic interactions. Compd. 2 shows the usual 1-dimensional antiferromagnetism, whereas 4 and 6 exhibit different weak ferromagnetism due to spin canting <13.8 and 4.6 K, resp.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXmtFCjtQ%253D%253D&md5=110ef091b83e9d7b6b767869be1cd600
        (d) Liu, Y.; Xuan, W.; Cui, Y. Adv. Mater. 2010, 22, 4112
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1d
        Engineering homochiral metal-organic frameworks for heterogeneous asymmetric catalysis and enantioselective separation
        Liu, Yan; Xuan, Weimin; Cui, Yong
        Advanced Materials (Weinheim, Germany) (2010), 22 (37), 4112-4135CODEN: ADVMEW; ISSN:0935-9648. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A review. Owing to the potential applications in technol. areas such as gas storage, catalysis, sepn., sensing and nonlinear optics, tremendous efforts were devoted to the development of porous metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) over the past ten years. Homochiral porous MOFs are particularly attractive candidates as heterogeneous asym. catalysts and enantioselective adsorbents and separators for prodn. of optically active org. compds. due to the lack of homochiral inorg. porous materials such as zeolites. In this review, the authors summarize the recent research progress in homochiral MOF materials, including their synthetic strategy, distinctive structural features and latest advances in asym. heterogeneous catalysis and enantioselective sepn.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhtlKks7zJ&md5=5fa5afa5c96afadf40412362ba6dd475
        (e) Hou, H. W.; Meng, X. R.; Song, Y. L.; Fan, Y. T.; Zhu, Y.; Lu, H. J.; Du, C. X.; Shao, W. H. Inorg. Chem. 2002, 41, 4068
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1e
        Two-Dimensional Rhombohedral Grid Coordination Polymers [M(bbbt)2(NCS)2]n (M = Co, Mn, or Cd; bbbt = 1,1'-(1,4-butanediyl)bis-1H-benzotriazole): Synthesis, Crystal Structures, and Third-Order Nonlinear Optical Properties
        Hou, Hongwei; Meng, Xiangru; Song, Yinglin; Fan, Yaoting; Zhu, Yu; Lu, Huijie; Du, Chenxia; Shao, Weihua
        Inorganic Chemistry (2002), 41 (15), 4068-4075CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Treatment of 1,1'-(1,4-butanediyl)bis-1H-benzotriazole (bbbt) and KSCN with Co(II), Mn(II), or Cd(II) afforded three two-dimensional rhombohedral grid coordination polymers [M(bbbt)2(NCS)2]n (M = Co, 1; Mn, 2; Cd, 3). The two-dimensional rhombohedral grids are parallel to the crystallog. ac plane. The rhombohedral grid consists of 44-membered rings of M4(bbbt)4, and gives the dimensions of 12.913 × 10.764 Å for polymer 1, 13.106 × 10.797 Å for polymer 2, and 13.256 × 10.870 Å for polymer 3. The three polymers' third-order nonlinear optical (NLO) properties were detd. by Z-scan technique in DMF soln. The results show that all three polymers show very large NLO absorption and strong NLO refraction properties. The third-order NLO absorptive coeffs. α2 are 5.4 × 10-9 m W-1 for polymer 1, 5.2 × 10-9 m W-1 for polymer 2, and 5.0 × 10-9 m W-1 for polymer 3. The α2 values are larger than those of all the reported cluster compds. The NLO refractive index values n2 of polymers 1-3 are 5.73 × 10-19, 3.55 × 10-19, and 3.07 × 10-19 m2 W-1, resp. Their hyperpolarizability γ values are 2.40 × 10-30 esu for polymer 1, 1.52 × 10-30 esu for polymer 2, and 1.50 × 10-30 esu for polymer 3. The γ values are comparable to those of clusters and better than those of organometallic compds., semiconductors, and fullerene.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XkvVGnu7g%253D&md5=6d3f8fcecf9efb5d8787896546030c3c
      2. 2
        (a) Cui, Y.; Evans, O. R.; Ngo, H. L.; White, P. S.; Lin, W. B. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2002, 41, 1159
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        2a
        Rational design of homochiral solids based on two-dimensional metal carboxylates
        Cui, Yong; Evans, Owen R.; Ngo, Helen L.; White, Peter S.; Lin, Wenbin
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2002), 41 (7), 1159-1162CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH)
        A chiral two-dimensional network is the basis for the structure of a homochiral solid exploiting metal-carboxylate coordination. The synthesis involved enantiopure bridging ligands and metal-org. secondary building units, and resulted in ethoxy-protected BINOL functionalities pointing into the cavities in this cryst. chiral zeolitic material. The cobalt, manganese and nickel-derived complexes of (1S)-6,6'-dichloro-2,2'-diethoxy-1,1'-binaphthalene-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid were reported. The cobalt-derived complex of (1R)-6,6'-dichloro-2,2'-diethoxy-1,1'-binaphthalene-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid was also reported; using either the (1S)-isomer or the (1R)-isomer, supramol. enantiomers were obtained.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XivVykt7o%253D&md5=b573002d44007cf995760a35be95734b

        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        2b
        Reticular synthesis and the design of new materials
        Yaghi, Omar M.; O'Keeffe, Michael; Ockwig, Nathan W.; Chae, Hee K.; Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Kim, Jaheon
        Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2003), 423 (6941), 705-714CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
        A review. The long-standing challenge of designing and constructing new cryst. solid-state materials from mol. building blocks is just beginning to be addressed with success. A conceptual approach that requires the use of secondary building units to direct the assembly of ordered frameworks epitomizes this process: the authors call this approach reticular synthesis. This chem. has yielded materials designed to have predetd. structures, compns. and properties. In particular, highly porous frameworks held together by strong metal-O-C bonds and with exceptionally large surface area and capacity for gas storage were prepd. and their pore metrics systematically varied and functionalized.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXksV2itro%253D&md5=2417c5adb0e948350d3d62350c8cd7ea
        (c) Reger, D. L.; Watson, R. P.; Smith, M. D. Inorg. Chem. 2006, 45, 10077
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        2c
        Silver(I) Complexes of Fixed, Polytopic Bis(pyrazolyl)methane Ligands: Influence of Ligand Geometry on the Formation of Discrete Metallacycles and Coordination Polymers
        Reger, Daniel L.; Watson, Russell P.; Smith, Mark D.
        Inorganic Chemistry (2006), 45 (25), 10077-10087CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Reactions of the arene-linked bis(pyrazolyl)methane ligands m-bis[bis(1-pyrazolyl)methyl]benzene, (m-[CH(pz)2]2C6H4, Lm), p-bis[bis(1-pyrazolyl)methyl]benzene, (p-[CH(pz)2]2C6H4, Lp), and 1,3,5-tris[bis(1-pyrazolyl)methyl]benzene (1,3,5-[CH(pz)2]3C6H3, L3) with AgX salts (pz = 1-pyrazolyl; X = BF4- or PF6-) yield two types of mol. motifs depending on the arrangement of the ligating sites about the central arene ring. Reactions of the m-phenylene-linked Lm with AgBF4 and AgPF6 afford complexes consisting of discrete, metallacyclic dications:[Ag2(μ-Lm)2](BF4)2 (1) and [Ag2(μ-Lm)2](PF6)2 (2). When the p-phenylene-linked Lp is treated with AgBF4 and AgPF6, acyclic, cationic coordination polymers were obtained:{[Ag(μ-Lp)]BF4}∞ (3) and {[Ag(μ-Lp)]PF6}∞ (4). Reaction of the ligand L3, contg. three bis(pyrazolyl)methane units in a meta arrangement, with an equimolar amt. of AgBF4 again yields discrete metallacyclic dications in which one bis(pyrazolyl)methane unit on each ligand remains unbound: [Ag2(μ-L3)2](BF4)2 (5). Treatment of L3 with an excess of AgBF4 affords a polymer of metallacycles, {[Ag3(μ-L3)2](BF4)3}∞ (6), with one of the bis(pyrazolyl)methane units on each ligand bound to a silver cation bridging two metallacycles. The supramol. structures of the silver(I) complexes 1-6 are organized by noncovalent interactions, including weak hydrogen bonding, π-π, and anion-π interactions.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XhtVyhtrzO&md5=09726720ecd4fe10fdd9fd1946ceb844
        (d) Luo, F.; Che, Y. X.; Zheng, J. M. Cryst. Growth Des. 2009, 9, 1066
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        2d
        Trinuclear Cobalt Based Porous Coordination Polymers Showing Unique Topological and Magnetic Variety upon Different Dicarboxylate-like Ligands
        Luo, Feng; Che, Yun-xia; Zheng, Ji-min
        Crystal Growth & Design (2009), 9 (2), 1066-1071CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        One-pot solvothermal self-assembly is employed to prep. Co3 based porous coordination polymers, viz. (1), [H2NMe2]2[Co3(i.p.)4]·H2O; (2), [H2NMe2]2[Co3(bdc)4]·(DMF)2; (3), [H2NMe2]2[Co3(bpdc)4]·(CH3OH)2(DMF)1.5, where i.p., bdc, bpdc, and DMF are 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate, 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylate, and N,N'-DMF, resp. Via different org. connectors such as i.p., bdc, and bpdc, such Co3 mol. building blocks (MBB), [Co3(CO2)8]2-, are assocd. together to give a tunable 8-connected topol. framework, viz. 42464 for 1, 36414576 for 2, and 36418536 for 3. Upon the geometry and the length of org. connectors, their corresponding porosity occupied by c counterions plus solvent mols. also can be tunable, for example, with the consideration of [H2NMe2]+ counterions, the solvent-accessible vol. is 460.2 Å3 for 1, equal to 23.9% of the cell vol., 3320.4 Å3 for 2, equal to 56.3% of the cell vol., 4107.2 Å3 for 3, equal to 50% of the cell vol. Notably, besides these outstanding features of tunable 8-connected topol. and porosity, their magnetic properties such as ferromagnetic behavior without magnetic ordering for 1, spin-canting and metamagnetic behavior with magnetic ordering for 2, as well as spin-canting, metamagnetic, and spin-glass behavior with magnetic ordering for 3 also can be tunable.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhsVGnsLrM&md5=c3077f5101e9d684b77ac34721e589f3
        (e) Qin, L.; Hu, J. S.; Li, Y. Z.; Zheng, H. G. Cryst. Growth Des. 2012, 12, 403
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        2e
        Effect of Carboxylate Coligands with Different Rigidity on Supramolecular Architectures Based on One Rigid Didentate Linear Ligand
        Qin, Ling; Hu, Jin-Song; Li, Yi-Zhi; Zheng, He-Gen
        Crystal Growth & Design (2012), 12 (1), 403-413CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        Six new metal-org. frameworks, namely, {[Cd(bpbenz)(pim)] }n (1), {[Cd(bpbenz)(sea)]·(H2O)2}n (2), {[Cd(bpbenz)(hfipbb)]·(H2O)3}n (3), {[Co(bpbenz)(4,4'-sdb)]·(H2O)2.75}n (4), {[Ni(bpbenz)(4,4'-sdb) (H2O)3]·(H2O)2}n (5), and {[Co(bpbenz)(Hbtc)]·(H2O) }n (6), [bpbenz = 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)benzene, pim = pimelic acid, sea = sebacic acid, H2hfipbb = 4,4'-(hexafluoroisopropylidene)bis(benzoic acid), 4,4'-H2sdb = 4,4'-sulfonyldibenzoic acid, H3btc = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid], have been synthesized under solvothermal conditions (DMF/H2O; DMF = N,N-dimethylacetamide). These compds. were characterized by elemental anal., IR spectroscopy, and x-ray single-crystal diffraction. Compd. 1 is a 3D network composed of layers of pentagonal-bipyramidal coordinated Cd atoms bridged by pimelic anions in syn-anti configurations and bpbenz mols. between layers with {412.63} pcu topol. In compd. 2, the bpbenz and sebacic anions act as bidentate ligands assembling with Cd(NO3)2 to a 2D framework. Compd. 3 is a 2D network composed of chains, which is bridged by the [Cd2(CO2)4]2L2 SBUs and hfipbb2- anions, and with bpbenz mols. between chains. For compd. 4, the bpbenz and 4,4'-sdb coordinate to Co cations to form a three-dimensional {65.8} cds uninodal network. Compd. 5 features 2D structure with inclined polycatenation (1D + 1D → 2D). For compd. 6, a 2D network with side arms gives a polythreaded network, which exhibits a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D array if H-bonds are taken into account. Magnetic susceptibility measurements indicate that compds. 4 and 6 have dominating antiferromagnetic couplings between metal ions. Furthermore, thermal stabilities for 1-6 and luminescent properties for 1-3 are also discussed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhsFSjsbbF&md5=6cff4364528f221946605967b5f7a5a2
      3. 3
        (a) Cao, R.; Sun, D. F.; Liang, Y. C.; Hong, M. C.; Tatsumi, K.; Shi, Q. Inorg. Chem. 2002, 41, 2087
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3a
        Syntheses and Characterizations of Three-Dimensional Channel-like Polymeric Lanthanide Complexes Constructed by 1,2,4,5-Benzenetetracarboxylic Acid
        Cao, Rong; Sun, Daofeng; Liang, Yucang; Hong, Maochun; Tatsumi, Kazuyuki; Shi, Qian
        Inorganic Chemistry (2002), 41 (8), 2087-2094CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        The hydrothermal reaction of YbCl3·6H2O with 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic dianhydride resulted in [{Yb(bbtec)1/4(dbtec)3/6(H2O)2}4·6H2O]n (1, H4btec = 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid), and the solvothermal reaction of Er(NO3)3·6H2O or TbCl3·6H2O with 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic dianhydride in H2O/acetic acid gave rise to [{Er2(cbtec)2/4(ebtec)2/4(fbtec)2/4(H2O)4}·4H2O]n (2) and [{Tb(H2btec)2/4(fbtec)3/6(H2O)}·2H2O]n (3), resp. Complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/m with a 20.8119(5), b 17.6174(1), c 5.7252(2) Å, β 92.324(1)°, and Z = 1. 1 Possesses a three-dimensional framework consisting of eight-coordinate ytterbium centers and two kinds of channels along the c axis. Complex 2 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P‾1 with a 9.6739(5), b 11.0039(5), c 11.5523 Å, α 104.8330(10), β 91.0000(10), γ 114.2570(10)°, and Z = 2. 2 Has a three-dimensional framework structure comprising both eight- and nine-coordinate erbium centers and channels along the a axis. Complex 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n with a 10.7246(12), b 7.1693(9), c 17.158(2) Å, β 97.109(2)°, and Z = 4. 3 Shows a three-dimensional framework contg. nine-coordinate terbium centers and channels along the b axis. Uncoordinated water mols. occupy the channels in the three complexes. TGA and XRPD were detd. for the three complexes, and the framework of 1 is retained upon removal of uncoordinated and coordinated water mols.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38Xit1Wht7k%253D&md5=3eb730b811ff32601a9993270a10f4ef
        (b) MacDonald, J. C.; Luo, T. J. M.; Palmore, G. T. R. Cryst. Growth Des. 2004, 4, 1203
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3b
        Supramolecular Behavior of an Isomorphous Series of Five Bis(2-methylimidazolium 2,6-dicarboxypyridine) M(II) Complexes
        MacDonald, John C.; Luo, Tzy-Jiun M.; Palmore, G. Tayhas R.
        Crystal Growth & Design (2004), 4 (6), 1203-1209CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        The supramol. chem. and crystal structures of five bis(2-methylimidazolium 2,6-dicarboxypyridine) M(II) complexes, where M = Zn, Cu, Ni, Co, and 7:3 Mn/Cu (1-5, resp.), are reported. These complexes form building blocks with nearly identical mol. structures that crystallize in the same packing pattern. Anions of 2,6-dicarboxypyridine and cations of 2-methylimidazole form N-H···O and O-H···O H bonds that dominate crystal packing by forming linear ribbons of mols. Thus, complexes 1-5 form an isomorphous series with a single robust cryst. architecture that accommodates five different transition metals without altering mol. packing. The growth of crystals from solns. that contain two different metal complexes produces mixed crystals in which mixts. of the different metal complexes are incorporated in the same relative molar ratio present in soln. This technique was used to grow crystals of 5 with Mn and Cu complexes in a 7:3 molar ratio. Complexes 1-5 form cryst. solids that represent a novel class of modular materials in which the org. ligands serve as a structural component that defines a single packing arrangement that persists over a range of structures and in which the metal serves as an interchangeable component with which to vary the phys. properties of the material. The mol. and crystal structures of bis(2-methylimidazolium 2,6-dicarboxypyridine) M(II) complexes 1-5 are reported and compared to those of a related family of bis(imidazolium 2,6-dicarboxypyridine) M(II) dihydrate complexes 1'-5' (M = Zn, Cu, Ni, Co, and Mn) reported previously. Complexes 1-5 and 1'-5' have similar packing arrangements and introducing a Me substituent (similar in size to H2O) at the C2 position of imidazole displaces H2O and prevents it from being incorporated into the lattice of 1-5.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXmtFamsL4%253D&md5=2d7d06ae579d3c172aab22eb655e28ac
        (c) Mahata, P.; Natarajan, S. Inorg. Chem. 2007, 46, 1250
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3c
        A New Series of Three-Dimensional Metal-Organic Framework, [M2(H2O)][C5N1H3(COO)2]3·2H2O, M = La, Pr, and Nd: Synthesis, Structure, and Properties
        Mahata, Partha; Natarajan, Srinivasan
        Inorganic Chemistry (2007), 46 (4), 1250-1258CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Lanthanide pyridinedicarboxylates, [M2(H2O)][C5N1H3(COO)2]3·2H2O, M = La (1), Pr (2), and Nd (3), were prepd. by the reaction of trivalent lanthanide salts and 2,3-pyridinedicarboxylic acid employing a mild condition hydrothermal reaction. The structures are built up from MO8N and MO7N2 (M = lanthanide) polyhedra connected to the dicarboxylate anions forming the three-dimensional structure with 1-dimensional channels. A striking feature of this structure is the presence of an unusual Z-shaped tetramer, M4O24N6. Extra-framework water mols., located within the open channels, are reversibly adsorbed. Detailed in situ and ex situ studies using FTIR and PXRD studies clearly show that the removal of the water mols. is reversible and accompanied by changes in the size of the channel. Partial substitution at the La sites by Eu gives rise to characteristic red-pink luminescence, indicating a ligand-sensitized metal-centered emission.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXktF2nuw%253D%253D&md5=87ded554f978365cd9b385a1291357e0
        (d) Wang, Z. W.; Ji, C. C.; Li, J.; Guo, Z. J.; Li, Y. Z.; Zheng, H. G. Cryst. Growth Des. 2009, 9, 475
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3d
        Synthesis, X-ray Structures, and Fluorescent Properties of Coordination Networks Constructed from 2-(2-Pyridinyl-benzimidazolyl) Acetic Anion
        Wang, Zuo-Wei; Ji, Chang-Chun; Li, Jing; Guo, Zi-Jian; Li, Yi-Zhi; Zheng, He-Gen
        Crystal Growth & Design (2009), 9 (1), 475-482CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        Four new metal coordination polymers, [Cd(pybma)2]n (1), [Zn(pybma)(C2O4)0.5·0.5H2O]n (2), [Co(pybma)(C2O4)0.5]n (3), and [Zn3(pybma)2(HBTC)2(H2O)4]n (4) [pybma = (2-(2-pyridinyl)benzimidazol-1-yl)acetate; H3BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate], were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions and structurally characterized by element analyses, IR spectroscopy, and single-crystal x-ray diffraction analyses. Has a 1-dimensional (1D) chain structure, which contains two kinds of rings. Has a two-dimensional (2D) metal-org. framework and can be seen as the unity of two parallel double-stranded helixes, in which the helixes are bridged by oxalate ligands. Has a 2-dimensional framework built from 1-dimensional chains and ox bridges. Has 2-dimensional layer framework which is assembled into a three-dimensional (3D) framework with two kinds of channels. Polymers 1, 2, and 4 exhibit obvious fluorescent emissions in the solid state at room temp.; no fluorescent emission is obsd. in polymer 3.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhsVShsb3P&md5=65a232f78f7db7d129f5ee9125d9ccee
        (e) Wang, S.; Yun, R. R.; Peng, Y.; Zhang, Q.; Lu, J.; Dou, J.; Bai, J.; Li, D.; Wang, D. Cryst. Growth Des. 2012, 12, 79
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3e
        A Series of Four-Connected Entangled Metal-Organic Frameworks Assembled from Pamoic Acid and Pyridine-Containing Ligands: Interpenetrating, Self-Penetrating, and Supramolecular Isomerism
        Wang, Suna; Yun, Ruirui; Peng, Yanqiang; Zhang, Qingfu; Lu, Jing; Dou, Jianmin; Bai, Junfeng; Li, Dacheng; Wang, Daqi
        Crystal Growth & Design (2012), 12 (1), 79-92CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        Five novel compds., {[Ni(PA)(bpe)(H2O)2]·DMF}n (1), {[Zn(PA)(bpe)]·DMF}n (2), {[Zn(PA)(bpe)]·2DMF·CH3OH}n (3), {[Cd2(PA)2(bpe)2(H2O)]·3.5H2O}n (4), {[Ni2(PA)2(bpp)2(H2O)3]·2DMF}n (5), based on pamoic acid (H2PA) (bpe = 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane, bpp = 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane) were synthesized. In such a system, both the PA2- anion ligand and dipyridyl ligands act as bipodal linkers, connecting the metal centers in square or tetrahedral geometries into 4-connected topologies with different entangled modes: 3-fold interpenetrating CdSO4 net (65.8) (1), roto-translational [2 + 2] interpenetrating diamond pseudosupramol. isomers (2 and 3), 3-fold interpenetrating (6.74.8)(64.7.8) (4) and (6.85)(64.82) net with both 2-fold interpenetrating and self-penetrating characters (5), resp. The formation of unique penetrating frameworks was studied. Gas adsorption and photoluminescent properties of the compds. also were explored.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Three-dimensional metal-organic framework with (3,4)-connected net, synthesized from an ionic liquid medium
        Dybtsev, Danil N.; Chun, Hyungphil; Kim, Kimoon
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2004), (14), 1594-1595CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A new 3-dimensional metal-org. framework with a (3,4)-connected network topol., [Cu3(tpt)4](BF4)3·(tpt)2/3·5H2O (1, tpt = 2,4,6-tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine) was synthesized from butylmethylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate as an ionic liq. medium and characterized by x-ray powder diffraction, IR spectroscopy, TGA and elemental anal. The highly sym. structure of 1 comprises doubly interpenetrating nets with the cubic-C3N4 topol.

        (b) Dong, Y. B.; Xu, H. X.; Ma, J. P.; Huang, R. Q. Inorg. Chem. 2006, 45, 3325

        4b
        Silver(I) Coordination Polymers Based on A Nano-Sized Bent Bis(3-acetylenylphenyl-(4-cyanophenyl))oxadiazole Ligand: The Role of Ligand Isomerism and the Templating Effect of Polyatomic Anions and Solvent Intermediates
        Dong, Yu-Bin; Xu, Hong-Xia; Ma, Jian-Ping; Huang, Ru-Qi
        Inorganic Chemistry (2006), 45 (8), 3325-3343CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        One nanosized oxadiazole bridging ligand, bis(3-acetylenylphenyl-(4-cyanophenyl))oxadiazole (L11), was designed and synthesized by the reaction of bis(3-iodophenyl)oxadiazole with 4-cyanophenylacetylene via a Sonogashira-Hagihara cross-coupling reaction. Eight Ag(I)-L11 coordination polymers with 1-, two-, or three-dimensional structures were successfully prepd. by the reaction of L11 with various Ag(I) salts in soln. New coordination polymers were fully characterized by IR spectroscopy, elemental anal., and single-crystal x-ray diffraction. All new complexes contain Ag heteroatom cluster-connecting nodes, and the L11 ligand is doubling up in the frameworks. In this Ag(I)-L11 system, the conformation of L11 is versatile because of the conformational rotation around the central oxadiazole moiety and depends greatly on the counterion and solvent system used in the formation of the complexes. The luminescence property and host-guest chem. of some complexes were studied primarily.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        4c
        Design and generation of extended zeolitic metal-organic frameworks (ZMOFs): synthesis and crystal structure of zinc(II) imidazolate polymers with zeolitic frameworks.
        Tian, Yun-Qi; Zhao, Yu-Ming; Chen, Zhen-Xia; Zhang, Guang-Ning; Weng, Lin-Hong; Zhao, Dong-Yuan
        Chemistry--A European Journal (2007), 13 (15), 4146-4154CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Attempts to create metal-org. frameworks (ZMOFs) with zeolitic topologies, metal (zinc(II) and cobalt(II)) imidazolates have repeatedly been used as the metal-org. motifs of inorg. silicate analogs. By modulating the synthetic strategy based on the solvothermal and liq. diffusion method, seven further MOFs (including at least three zeolitic MOFs) of Zn(II) imidazolates, [Zn(Im)2·xG] (G = guest mol. (diethylformamide (DEF), 3-methyl-1-butanol (MB), dimethylacetamide (DMA), DMF, N-methylpyrrolidone (NMP), x = 0.2-1)) 1a-7a, were successfully synthesized. Of these, 1a-3a (G = DEF-MB, DMA-NMP, DMF, resp.) are isostructural with the previously reported Co analogs 1b-3b, resp., while 4a-7a (G = DMF, DMF-DMA-NMP, DEF< DEF, resp.) are new members of the metal imidazolate MOF family. Complex 4a exhibits a structure related to silicate CaAl2Si2O8 of CrB4 topol., but with a higher network symmetry; complex 5a has a structure with zeolitic DFT topol. that was discovered in zeolite-related materials of DAF-2, UCSB-3, and UCSB-3GaGe; complex 6a demonstrates an unprecedented zeolite-like topol. with one dimensional channels with 10-rings; and 7a displays a structure of natural zeolite GIS (gismondine) topol. All of these polymorphous MOFs were created only by using certain solvents as structure-directing agents (SDAs). Further extensive metal-org. frameworks with zeolitic topologies can be envisaged if other solvents were to be used.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        4d
        Solvent induced reactivity of 3,5-dimethylpyrazole towards zinc(II) carboxylates
        Sarma, Rupam; Kalita, Dipjyoti; Baruah, Jubaraj B.
        Dalton Transactions (2009), (36), 7428-7436CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The reactions of 3,5-dimethylpyrazole with zinc(II) acetate dihydrate and varieties of arom. carboxylic acids led to formation of mononuclear zinc complexes [Zn(HDMP)2(RCO2)2] (R = C6H5, p-CH3-C6H4, p-NO2-C6H4 etc., HDMP = 3,5-dimethylpyrazole) in MeOH, whereas the same reactants in DMF gave binuclear 3,5-dimethylpyrazolato bridged zinc carboxylate complexes contg. monodentate 3,5-dimethylpyrazole ligands with compn. [Zn2(μ-DMP)2(HDMP)2(RCO2)2]. The mononuclear complexes can be converted to the corresponding binuclear complexes by simply dissolving in DMF. The reaction of zinc(II) acetate dihydrate with p-nitrobenzoic acid and 3,5-dimethylpyrazole in different solvents gave solvated mononuclear complexes of the corresponding solvent. All these solvated complexes having the core [Zn(HDMP)2(p-NO2-C6H4CO2)2] contain two structurally independent mols. in the asym. unit (Z' = 2).

        Masaoka, Shigeyuki; Tanaka, Daisuke; Nakanishi, Yasunori; Kitagawa, Susumu

Bridging of Cu ions can occur via benzoquinone or acetate O atoms. All 3 isomers were characterized by x-ray crystallog.

        Temperature-dependent supramolecular stereoisomerism in porous copper coordination networks based on a designed carboxylate ligand
        Sun, Daofeng; Ke, Yanxiong; Mattox, Tracy M.; Ooro, Betty A.; Zhou, Hong-Cai
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2005), (43), 5447-5449CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)

The polymeric complexes have PtS and NbO net topologies, resp. The polymeric complexes have similar thermal stabilities and their Langmuir surface areas and hydrogen storage capacities were detd.

        Temperature Controlled Reversible Change of the Coordination Modes of the Highly Symmetrical Multitopic Ligand To Construct Coordination Assemblies: Experimental and Theoretical Studies
        Zheng, Bo; Dong, Hao; Bai, Junfeng; Li, Yizhi; Li, Shuhua; Scheer, Manfred
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2008), 130 (25), 7778-7779CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        By fine-tuning the reaction temp. to 5, 15, 30, and 50°, resp., four different complexes, [Cd(HC4O4)2(H2O)4] (1), [Cd4(C4O4)4(H2O)16]•(H2O)2 (2), [Cd(C4O4)(H2O)2] (3), and [Cd(C4O4)(H2O)2] (4), were formed successfully from the identical initial reaction mixt. contg. Cd(OH)2 and squaric acid. The four complexes were characterized by x-ray crystallog. Also, an unprecedented reversible interconversion among the four complexes at the corresponding reaction temps. mediated by the mother liquor was obsd.

        5d
        Temperature-Controlled Synthesis of Metal-Organic Coordination Polymers: Crystal Structure, Supramolecular Isomerism, and Porous Property
        Kanoo, Prakash; Gurunatha, K. L.; Maji, Tapas Kumar
        Crystal Growth & Design (2009), 9 (9), 4147-4156CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        Five new supramol. metal-org. coordination polymers (MOCPs), {[Ni(bipy) (H2O)4](2,6-nds)·4H2O} (1), {[Ni(bipy)(H2O)4](2,6-nds)·2H2O} (2), {[Ni (bipy)(H2O)4](2,6-nds)} (3), {[Ni (bipy)(H2O)4](2,6-nds)} (4), {[Cu (bipy)(H2O)4](2,6-nds)} (5) (bipy = 4,4'-bipyridyl; 2,6-nds = 2,6-naphthalenedisulfonate) have been synthesized and structurally characterized. Compds. 1 and 5 were synthesized at room temp. in H2O/EtOH medium, whereas 2-4 were isolated under hydrothermal conditions. Compds. 1-4 were synthesized maintaining the same stoichiometric ratio of metal and ligand under different reaction temps., and the different structures of the compds. indicate that the temp. plays a significant role in the construction of the coordination polymers. Structural characterization reveals that the one-dimensional [M(bipy)(H2O)4]2+ cationic chain is a basic building unit for all of the MOCPs, while 2,6-nds remains as a counteranion. In all cases, 2,6-nds counteranions interact with water and bipy mols. through strong hydrogen-bonding and π-π interactions to afford three-dimensional supramol. structures. Compds. 1-4 have the same building unit with different network superstructures and are related as supramol. isomers. Supramol. isomerism in 3 and 4 is very interesting since they have the same mol. formula, {[Ni(bipy)(H2O)4](2,6-nds)}, and are polymorphs. Compds. 4 and 5 are isomorphous. The thermogravimetric study suggests that the dehydrated compds. are stable up to 300°. Furthermore, sorption studies suggest that dehydrated compds. of 1 and 2 are permanently porous.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXpvV2nsb4%253D&md5=e7efb7696e37adb4c0d793bff194b0f0

        From molecules to crystal engineering. Supramolecular isomerism and polymorphism in network solids
        Moulton, Brian; Zaworotko, Michael J.
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, D. C.) (2001), 101 (6), 1629-1658CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)

        A review. This article summarizes the recent advances in the crystal growth, structural control strategies and diverse structures of the binary metal imidazolate and triazolate frameworks, which are the simplest systems for crystal engineering of two-, three- and four-connected coordination polymers.

        7c
        Interpenetrating copper-silver cyanometallate networks: polymorphs and topological isomers
        Chippindale, Ann M.; Cheyne, Simon M.; Hibble, Simon J.
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2005), 44 (48), 7942-7946CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Newly prepd. mixed Cu(I)-Ag(I) cyanide complexes A[Ag2Cu(CN)4] (A = K, Rb, Cs) form interpenetrating layer structures and three-dimensional networks. Two different forms of the Rb and Cs compds. are obsd., which are both topol. isomers and polymorphs.

        8a
        Supramolecular isomerism in coordination polymers: conformational freedom of ligands in [Co(NO3)2(1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane)1.5]n
        Hennigar, Tracy L.; MacQuarrie, Donald C.; Losier, Pierre; Rogers, Robin D.; Zaworotko, Michael J.
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition in English (1997), 36 (9), 972-973CODEN: ACIEAY; ISSN:0570-0833. (VCH)
        The dramatic effect on network morphol. that conformational freedom is a ligand can impart to a coordination polymer is reported. 1,2-Bis(4-pyridyl)ethane (L), able to adopt gauche or anti conformations, and [Co(NO3)2L1.5]n (I) can exist in at least 3 different supramol. isomers. Thus I was prepd. and characterized by crystal structural anal., identifying 3 entirely different network structures. In one conformer 2 L are gauche and 1 anti whereas in the 2nd conformer 2 are anti and 1 gauche and in the 3rd all are anti.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2sXjsVCkt7o%253D&md5=5ed6888d0fbf71249547689767942891

        8b
        Supramolecular Isomerism in Coordination Compounds: Nanoscale Molecular Hexagons and Chains
        Abourahma, Heba; Moulton, Brian; Kravtsov, Victor; Zaworotko, Michael J.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2002), 124 (34), 9990-9991CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A nanoscale supramol. hexagon, [Cu6(5-NO2-bdc)6(DMSO)6(MeOH)3(H2O)9] (1), and its supramol. isomeric polymeric chain structure, [Cu2(DMSO)2(MeOH)(H2O)3]n (2), were prepd. from self-assembly of H25-NO2-bdc (5-nitrobenzene-1,3-dicarboxylic acid) and Cu(II) cations. The hexagon is neutral and sol. and has outer and inner diams. of 3.1 and 0.8 nm, resp.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XlvVWqurw%253D&md5=72c3551164b9635b9617071b1da70749

        8c
        Two supramolecular isomers of molecular squares and 1D helical chains with alternating right- and left-handed chirality
        Jiang, Long; Lu, Tong-Bu; Feng, Xiao-Long
        Inorganic Chemistry (2005), 44 (20), 7056-7062CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        The reaction of [Ni(α-rac-L)](ClO4)2 with K2[Ni(CN)4] gives a cyanide bridged [2+2] type of mol. square, {cis-[Ni(f-rac-L)][Ni(CN)4]}2 (1). By slightly changing the reaction conditions, the reaction of [Ni(α-rac-L)](ClO4)2 with KCN leads to a metastable compd., cis-[Ni(f-rac-L)(CN)2] (2), and an unexpected 1-dimensional helical chain, {cis-[Ni(f-rac-L)][Ni(CN)4]}n (3). In 3, the 1-dimensional helical chains are packed in an alternating right- and left-handed chirality due to the oppositely twisted arrangements of two adjacent [Ni(CN)4]2- anions. The metastable compd. 2 can be converted to 3 in a MeCN/MeOH soln. Compds. 1 and 3 are classified as supramol. isomers, and isomer 3 can be considered to be formed by the ring-opening polymn. of the square precursor 1. Magnetic susceptibility measurements of 1 and 3 show that the adjacent six-coordinated Ni(II) atoms are antiferromagnetically coupled through the bent -NC-Ni-CN- bridges of the diamagnetic [Ni(CN)4]2- anions, with g = 2.08 and J = -0.426 cm-1 for 1 and g = 2.08 and J = - 0.278 cm-1 for 3. The correlation between the structures and the J values is discussed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXpsVSksbg%253D&md5=0d2ed48d9d9f81c71579fbe8a030b8e1
        (d) Salsman, J. C.; Kubiak, C. P. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2005, 127, 2382
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        8d
        Mixed Valence Isomers
        Salsman, J. Catherine; Kubiak, Clifford P.; Ito, Tasuku
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2005), 127 (8), 2382-2383CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The IR spectroscopic observation of mixed valence isomers, the 2 alternate charge distributions of a mixed valence complex, is reported. Asymmetry induced by the 2-methylpyrazine bridging ligand was used to energetically differentiate the 2 states, and isotopic labeling of CO was used to spectroscopically observe the 2 states. IR line shape anal. was used to det. rate consts. for electron transfer of 6.5 × 1011 s-1 and equil. consts. of 2.2 for the mixed valence isomers.

        A new type of entangled coordination network: coexistence of polythreading and polyknotting involved molecular braids
        Gu, Zhi-Guo; Xu, Xin-Xin; Zhou, Wen; Pang, Chun-Yan; Bao, Fei-Fei; Li, Zaijun
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2012), 48 (26), 3212-3214CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A fascinating polythreaded coordination network {[Co(HL)(H2O)4][Co3(L)2(H2O)10]}n·4nH2O (where H3L = 5-(4-carboxy-2-nitrophenoxy)isophthalic acid) formed by 1-dimensional crankshaft shaped chains threading into a 2-dimensional undulated sheet in a 1-over/one-under interweaving fashion is reported, in which the 2-dimensional layer exhibits an unusual polyknotted entanglement contg. triple-stranded mol. braids.

Magnetic study shows that compd. 1 exhibits coexistence of paramagnetism and canted antiferromagnetism with Tc of 48 K.

        10a
        An unprecedented 2D → 3D metal-organic polyrotaxane framework constructed from cadmium and a flexible star-like ligand
        Wu, Hua; Liu, Hai-Yan; Liu, Ying-Ying; Yang, Jin; Liu, Bo; Ma, Jian-Fang
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2011), 47 (6), 1818-1820CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        [Cd(Tipa)Cl2]n·1.07nH2O (1), an unprecedented 2-dimensional → 3-dimensional metal-org. polyrotaxane framework, based on a new star-like tri(4-imidazolylphenyl)amine ligand (Tipa), was synthesized and characterized by single crystal x-ray diffraction anal., luminescence and TGA. 1 Which represents the 1st example of 2-dimensional → 3-dimensional polyrotaxane entangled in a parallel fashion.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXht1Wgsrk%253D&md5=d4997cc594b58c3c3bab77b5485d55ae
